author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> For the action items, does this seem correct?

- @jacekglen to share the updated rsults for Gas Cost Estimator

- (unassigned) to explore the impact of different repricing approaches on mainnet transaction throughput

- (unassigned) to prepare a EIP proposal for adjusting the pricing of one or more operations based on the benchmark results

- Possibly @MarekM25 / @ben_a_adams to investigate the feasibility and implications of using gas smuggling to decouple gas refunds from block gas usage

- Possibly @davidecrapis to schedule follow-up call to discuss medium-term gas pricing roadmap

- @nero_eth to share his work on block-level state warming

author: bridge-bot
content: <kevaundray> I think one implicit item is deciding on which benchmarking tool to use, or if both are to be used, how the data is normalized to suggest new gas numbers that are consistent with both tools

author: bridge-bot
content: <rjected> One q wrt @jacekglen 's benchmarker, how client agnostic is it / is there a repo and instructions I can check out? I know the nethermind benchmarker is engine api bound, but concretely how does this one work?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> The repository is here: https://github.com/imapp-pl/gas-cost-estimator


I've not looked into how it works though (re @rjected: One q wrt @jacekglen 's benchmarker, how client agnostic is it / is there a repo and instructions I can check out? I know the nethermind benchmarker is engine api bound, but concretely how does this one work?)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> Skimming it, here is how it looks like it works:

- A CLI tool is added to the client code
- This CLI takes in two inputs; bytecode and sample size(ie number of iterations to benchmark)
- The CLI then:
   - Sets up a fresh EVM instance
   - Sets up the calldata
   - Benchmarks the bytecode plus calldata using the languages native benchmarking tool. For Geth this would be the go testing framework
- The benchmark results is printed to stdout and the gas-cost estimator will extract this data

author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> So I guess in terms of client agnosticity, its not much compared to the nethermind tool which uses a standardized interface, but it seems most of the complexity is in the gas-cost estimator tool as it needs to parse the output from a specific client's language benchmarking tool. 

See here: https://github.com/imapp-pl/gas-cost-estimator/blob/29b0139371f2436e4d53a2efad292b47c5c5e5fc/src/instrumentation_measurement/measurements.py#L113
